description.narrative: This project is geared towards providing strategic support to the Government of Papua New Guinea in reducing vulnerability and increasing resilience to disasters.

1. New DRM Framework developed 2. Number of Disaster Management Plans and Standard Operating Procedures developed 3. Number of Disaster Risk Management integrated plans developed 4. Early Recovery Framework developed 5. Disaster Monitoring System strengthened

comment.narrative: 1. Outdated National Disaster Risk Management Framework 2. Disaster Risk Management Capacities at sub-national level is weak 3. Opportunities exists for Disaster Risk Management integration at different levels 4. Early Recovery Framework 5. Disaster Management Team in Place and meeting regularly

Activity Result 4: Capacity of the Disaster Management Team members and the National Disaster Centre to prepare and respond to disasters enhanced. Targets: 1. 1xDMT Annual Terms of Reference, Work Plan and Compact on accountability in place. 2. 1xAROB preparedness to respond to disasters and emergencies is improved. 3. 1xDisaster Management Team is prepared to respond to multi - hazard sudden - and - slow - onset events and crisis. 4. 1xTechnical inputs to DIsater Management Act have been incorporated.

1. DMT annual terms of reference, annual work plan and compact on accountability endorsed at 28 February meeting 2. 15 DMT meetings (6 ad hoc, 7 regular, 1 donor briefing, 1 CERF refresher workshop) 3. 6 ICCG meetings (2 for refugee emergency response, 2 for COVID-19 planning, 2 for La Niña planning) 4. Monitored/reported more than 30 disaster events, including La Niña, African Swine Fever, Fall Army Worm infestation, hydrometeorological events, seismic events, and conflicts 5. Facilitated the monitoring/transition of the refugee emergency response plan 6. Coordinated the production, revision and monitoring of the DMT COVID-19 multi-sector response plan, including financial tracking and 4Ws. 7. The ICCG reviewed and updated the slow- and sudden-onset plans, including in-country staffing and resources and surge capacity, to draft a La Niña contingency plan 8. Facilitated a review of the 1984 Disaster Management Act with Government, non-governmental and faith-based organizations, key donors and the Red Cross Movement. 9. 11 communities have successfully constructed water harvesting systems. 3 communities have received training on Covid- 19 and capacity-building activities on water, sanitation and hygiene management, and 9 communities received training on maintenance of the water catchment systems.

1. 1 Draft NDRRF Action Plan 2. 1 DRM Capacity Needs Assessment Report 3. 6 DRM capacity development plans 4. 1 National Disaster Loss Database 5. 1 DRM Training package with all key modules 6. 5 Trainings for Provincial Disaster Committees 7. 5 Provincial DM offices equipped 8. 3 DRM Awareness Products 9. Awareness Raising and Tsunami Evacuation Drills in 5 schools 10. Final MTDP with DRR indicators 11. 5 Multi Hazard Risk Assessment for 5 provinces 12. 5 Provincial Risk Profiles 13. 5 Provincial Risk Reduction Plans 14. 2 Trainings in Hazard and Risk Assessment 15. 5 Provincial DM Plans 16. 5 Provincial SOPs 17. 1 Govt Approved National Recovery Framework 18. 2 approved provincial recovery plans 19. 30 - number of persons trained on recovery planning 20. 20 - number of persons trained in post disaster damage and needs assessment 21. 1 NDC endorsed Recovery Damage Assessment process 22. 1 Disaster Recovery Project Catalogue 23. 10 DMT meetings, 2 functioning humanitarian clusters, 5 coordination meetings, 4 Inter cluster group meetings 24. 1 revised rapid assessment tool, 11 humanitarian bulletins, 1 x draft guidelines on the use of FMA, 1xCBi Workshop, 5 x disaster impact models (provincial), 1 x disaster impact model (national) 25. 1 x set of multi sectoral standardization relief item list 26. 4 x UNRC Meeting with Government 27. 1 x SOP on accessing International Assistance 28. 5,000 people of Pari having access to safe and clean water & Reduce water borne diseases 29. Increase lake retention volume to accommodate 6,000 cubic meters of fresh water 30. 2 automatic weather stations installed 31. 4 Automatic Weather Stations upgraded 32. 1 Policy/Information Paper for EPWG 13 (SOM1) 33. 1 PNG Presentation for EPWG 13 (SOM 1) 34. 1 Project Review Report 35. 1 Proposal for Phase II

1. NDRRF TWG established with initial discussions 2. Series of consultations held with NDC 3. Consultations held with development partners and Ministers office 4. Capacity Assessment for the 5 Provinces completed. 5. NDC Capacity assessment completed & shared with NDC. 6. Capacity Development plans for 5 provinces and NDC developed 7. Data entry & verification exercise 8. Training Manual Development in progress 9. Launch of database deferred to 2019 10. Review of CHARM training course finalized and submitted to UPNG 11. Activity postponed due to EQ. Pending NDC approval and involvement on the review of the training course 12. Discussion with NDC and the Provinces 13. Labelling of Equipment 14. Registering equipment on UNDP handover templates 15. Formal Handover of equipment to NDC 16. Series of Tsunami related awareness raising products produced. Other activities deferred to 2019. 17. All activities completed successfully, under leadership of NDC and jointly with DMPGM, POMGO, Education Department, Provincial Authorities, School administrations, schoolchildren and community members. 18. Support Rigo District to integrate DRR and Climate Change into its 5-year development plan 19. Integrate DRR and Climate Change indicators into PNG Medium Term Development Plan (2018-2022) 20. Submit provincial risk assessment reports to provinces to inform provincial development planning process 21. Provincial risk profiles completed and handed over to the provinces 22. Final draft of provincial risk reduction plans submitted to Govt for review and finalization 23. Training on Tsunami Risk Assessment (INSPIRE) 24. Training on Tsunami Evacuation Planning (ESCAPE) 25. DM Plans and SOPs completed 26. SOPs covering Flood, Landslide, Volcano Eruption, Earthquake, Tsunami, Marine Search and Rescue, Fire Protection and SOPs for Developing SOPs developed. 27. Final Draft Framework submitted to Earthquake Coordinator and NDC for review, approval and application for EQ recovery work. 28. Provincial recovery plans submitted to provincial administrations for review and endorsement. 29. Originally trainings were planned following approval of the Framework. Activity postponed due to EQ. 30. Originally trainings were planned following approval of the Framework. Activity postponed due to EQ. 31. Recovery needs assessment incorporated into NDCs multi-sectoral assessment methodology 32. Final draft project catalogue developed and submitted to NDC 33. Required DMT meetings completed, with functioning humanitarian clusters and coordination meetings conducted. 34. NDC Rapid Needs Assessment tool revised and Standby Joint Interagency Needs Assessment Team established 35. Technical Support and Capacity Building conducted for Clusters 36. UNRCs coordination meetings with Governments conducted. 37. Discussions underway 38. Activities moved to GEF Project 39. Activities moved to GEF Project 40. Activities completed in partnership with National Weather Service 41. Contracting completed. Field work planned for Q1 2019 42. Policy support provided to CCDA EPWG based on PNGs DRR/DRM context in preparation for SDMOF. 43. Supported CCDA in the hosting of SDMOF leading up to APEC meetings 44. The review of the first phase of the project was successfully completed 45. Consultations ongoing. Drafting process initiated.

1. 1 draft NDRRF Action Plan 2. 1 draft Monitoring & Reporting Tool for NDRRF 3. 1 DRM Capacity Needs Assessment and Capacity Development Plan 4. 1 Resourcing Plan for NDC 5. 1 Disaster Loss Database (including records for at least 5 Provinces) 6. 5 Provincial DM offices equipped 7. 5 Final MHRA and Risk Reduction Plans 8. 2 Provincial Implementation plans for NDRRF in draft 9. 1 Provincial or District Development Plan with DRR elements 10. 1 Government Submission (National Recovery Framework) 11. 1 approved provincial recovery plan 12. 1 El Nino Early Action Plan 13. 5 DMT Meetings 14. 50% of resources mobilized for EAP 15. 1 operational inter-cluster group meeting 16. 1 rapid assessment tool training package 17. 2 assessment training sessions 18. 1 assessment report produced 19. 1 draft plan on engaging private sector in DM

Apart from achieving all set targets, through this Project, UNDP’s investment in disaster preparedness saw the development of three national plans. These plans have been developed with the National Disaster Centre, selected Provincial Governments and members of the national Disaster Management Team. These plans will address respectively a: slow onset (El Niño) event; mid-scale multi-hazard sudden onset event; and a conflict/civil unrest event. that address how the international humanitarian actors in PNG will support the government to respond to sudden and slow-onset natural hazards, as well as a conflict/civil unrest scenario in Bougainville and a refugee emergency along the border with Indonesia. With these plans, regardless of the hazard that causes the emergency, the immediate impacts are predictable and, therefore, the response for these can be planned.
PNG’s Disaster Management Team (DMT) is the coordination body for international humanitarian assistance. With the UNDP’s support and through the Project, the DMT is now better prepared to quickly and effectively coordinate international humanitarian assistance for a variety of natural disasters and human-induced crises that are likely to occur in the country over the next year. The Government knows what it can expect from international humanitarian partners when the next disaster occurs, and how it will coordinate with DMT members and partners. Development partners/donors are confident that the international humanitarian community are prepared to effectively coordinate humanitarian assistance in support of Government and national partners.
Early warning measures planned under the stewardship of the National Disaster Centre and the Ntional Weather Service have been slowed by similar changes in leadership in this institution. Matters are complicated Government’s continuing budget pressures which have affected recurrent budgetary flows across a range of departments.
